job_title: Program Officer
pros:
I work full time at HRF.  The work-life balance is excellent with no set hours and the ability to work from home--except during conferences where you can kiss goodbye to work life balance as everyone pitches in to create what, year after year, is hands-down the best production experience I have ever seen.  

The job offers me the ability to travel globally and visit and work with world-class human rights defenders while traveling comfortably (we are consistently allowed to stay in good hotels and out flights, though coach, and never multiple layovers). Good pay for the limited amount of stress and pressure in non-conference periods. Great office located right in the middle of Koreatown with an unbeatable view.  Lots of team-building lunches and dinners and a spectacular brain trust in the office.  I love working here. The mission is unlike  any other at a human rights group. I would recommend HRF to anyone who wants to learn the nuts and bolts of effective human rights campaigning and see the impact of their work on the lives of those most oppressed.

The truth is the organization is 15 years old and will weather the nastiness of 2019.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Quality of work: Through the annual operation, everyone gets the opportunity to learn about the world and travel (everyone gets to travel internationally at least once a year to the Oslo Freedom Forum in Norway). Everyone gets to understand and experience the important differences between democracies and dictatorships through the organization’s work, and to personally meet activists on the ground that fight against dictatorship. If you really appreciate the democratic system (whether in the U.S., Canada or Costa Rica or Spain), and really have a disdain for governments who rule tyrannically around the world (from North Korea, Russia, to China, to Iran), you cannot find a better organization in the human rights movement to work for.

Compensation and work-life balance: Great salaries overall, considering the rest of the nonprofit industry. I started as an intern and was paid $1,000 per month at a time when Human Rights Watch did not pay interns. Excellent health, dental, vision and other benefits. Flexible policy on employees working remotely. I also knew of an employee that, as part of her work arrangement, did not come in on Fridays.

Size: Also a pro, but with downsides, the organization remains relatively small, with employees never exceeding 30 at any given time. This allows the organization flexibility to act quickly in campaigns when activists get imprisoned, but it also diminishes opportunities for long-term career promotions and significant compensation in an extremely expensive city like New York, which can be challenging.

Management: People in management are very professional, and keen on receiving feedback, and acting to improve and fix any perceived shortcomings. This is also a positive aspect of the organization remaining relatively small. Management is majority female, which reflects the overall demographics of the organization.

Domestic v. International Politics: The organization generally does NOT engage in domestic political debates. However, the organization does engage democratic governments in an attempt to make them allies in exposing the issues in authoritarian regimes, and to make them understand the dangers of authoritarianism taking over, even in democratic nations.

Diversity: Truly diverse work environment. The organization has employees from 10 or 12 different countries in the world and the founder is an open LGBTQ person and advocate for minority rights both in the U.S. and in the countries that repress sexual-orientation minorities (Chechnya, China, Iran, Cuba, Saudi Arabia, etc.). A lot of organizations pay lip service to diversity but HRF truly embodies this diversity—people from different ethnic and cultural backgrounds, who agree that exposing authoritarianism should the top priority to fix the world. The organization is two thirds female—including in management—and my experience is that they are considerate and excellent professionals—from universities that are top notch: Columbia, Stanford, Penn, etc. 

As to recent unfair bad reviews on Glassdoor: I have attended multiple Oslo Freedom Forums. The organization carries out several large conferences around the world. In my more than 5 years in the organization, I have never seen anyone from management or the president, or any male staff doing anything inappropriate, nor have I witnessed or heard about actions that would be considered sexual harassment against any man or woman whether on staff or not. Most of the male employees are openly gay (the organization is largely female and gay men outnumber straight men). Anonymous Glassdoor accusations that the organization is always “siding with the offender” and that “rampant sexual harassment” happens are absolutely false. For what I’ve asked around, I heard there were two incidents over ten years where a conference attendee behaved inappropriately. These individuals (who are not members of staff but conference attendees) allegedly made advances to members of staff (for context, these weren’t accusations of rape or groping—but broad unwelcome advances by a drunkard conference attendee at a bar). The reaction from management upon finding out was swift and forceful. These people were told they were NOT welcome and disinvited to attend any future conference. So, the organization sided immediately with the person making the accusation. Management did not consider any “due process” of the accused, but instead immediately acted to listen to and believe the victim, and to disinvite the suspected offender. I agree with this position because, especially in times of the #metoo movement, it is absolutely understandable to NOT give the benefit of the doubt to any conference attendee that gets drunk and as much as appear as acting in any way inappropriately with regard to a member of staff (or any other conference attendee), whether female or male.
cons: No 401K plan. There is no system in place to determine regularity of salary raises. Also, compensation tends to fluctuate with economic cycles that affect donations. Because of this lack of process, people who are more persistent at requesting raises and promotions might end up doing better than others at a particular point in time.

job_title: Anonymous Employee
pros:
Led by people who really care about the cause. Open door policy and friendly coworkers. Everyone is passionate about the cause and you learn a lot quickly because it's easy to ask questions and get answers. International travel opportunities are open to even lower level employees. Unlimited PTO with no guilt-tripping from coworkers or superiors. Employer-paid health insurance. You get to meet some amazing people in human rights, policy, and international politics on the job, and get the opportunity to form friendships with those people. There's quite a bit of room to create your ideal position based on your own interest, and to work across team boundaries.


If you're a self-starter, believe in the mission statement, open-minded, and are open to doing a variety of work that isn't strictly limited to your job description, then this is a good place for you. If you're someone who enjoys a corporate setting where everyone has their own office with clearly laid-out and followed job descriptions then this is probably not the place for you.
cons:
No 401k or annual pay raise structure. If you have new ideas, sometimes you have to insist on them and fight for them. Upper management takes some getting used to - each person has a different working style and strong personalities, and could be frustrating if you are not adaptable to each, but once you figure it out and set boundaries it works fine. Organization as a whole lacks robust processes, but that's partially intentional because management doesn't believe in bureaucracy in such a small organization. So the up side of this is that at times everyone feels equal and can have their ideas heard, but the downside is that sometimes efficiency is lower because of the lack of processes. A good percentage of the staff is based remotely so sometimes there's a disconnect in communications between staff and teams.


None of the problems at HRF is unique to this organization, and overall the pros of working here outweigh the cons.

job_title: Program Officer in Brooklyn, NY
pros:
I have been working at HRF full-time for more than a year

Fierce, smart and caring. The foundation is a mid-size organization where everyone on the "Team" really puts everything into making it successful on a daily basis. Employees rely on each other to pull their weight to get the job done. My experience is that all staff is super kind and treats each other well and genuinely cares for each other. I have not come across any malice or office politics as of the time of this review. The CEO , Chief Strategy, and Chief Legal officers are workaholics and their emails are coming in at 3AM and 4AM and sometimes they look haggard on google hangouts because they worked after hours, I sense they are very passionate about the mission of HRF.  

With the WFH and Stay Home directive I have come to appreciate the amount they juggle each and every day. It's astounding, all the while truly caring for the employees. the Chief Talent Officer is in charge of HR and she is always responsive. And when I say these people are "juggling" I mean handling geo-political issues that have consequence—from films the foundation has produced that premiere at Sundance Film Festival to world-important conferences and events. 

Before Corona took over the known universe HRF was way ahead of everyone with a network of people inside China informing on what was coming so the foundation took measures weeks before the U.S. was paralyzed. This special place is a school for heroes and I’m so happy I get to be a part of it. I work with incredibly devoted and decent people and learn every day on the job. review_title: Inappropriate Leadership, No Procedures or Protocol, Overworked and Underpaid
job_title: Coordinator in New York, NY
pros:
The only reason I continued dragging myself to this organization every day (besides the need for money) was that the team I worked directly with consisted of some of the most passionate, creative, talented people I know, who became real friends and role models to me. Fortunately, those people have now all left HRF, too, for better opportunities.

Besides a few friends, the only other things I got out of HRF were unbelievably appalling stories of employee mistreatment and a long list of red flags to look out for at other organizations.
cons:
I worked at HRF full time for 2 years. The wildly inappropriate behavior I witnessed and experienced at this organization from top-level leadership is shocking to everyone I tell the stories to. 

This organization, though it’s 10 years old, still operates like a disorganized start-up in the early stages. Employees in the NY office are crammed into a loud and hectic “open office” space. No retirement plan, professional development budget, or home office stipends. No HR department, no real procedure or protocol for anything, no solid job descriptions or reporting structure (at least none that are actually adhered to), and sexual assault claims are dismissed and berated.

Contractors have gone unpaid for months or longer. Mid and lower-level employees are severely overworked and underpaid, and often expected to be available at all hours. I would often work on my commute, all day without a lunch break, on my commute back, and then again at home on a minimal starting salary. Pleas for more staff would be dismissed due to finances, while we continued to struggle to manage the workload of 2-3 people each. Employees regularly experienced chest pains, anxiety attacks, ulcers, etc. from the stress.

High turnover rate and lack of sufficient staff means positions are often billed to potential employees as being able to create your own job description, with opportunities for rapid advancement, and the opportunity to work with a "growing/changing organization" - that means you'll be constantly overworked and asked to do things way outside of the job description you signed up for.

While core and lower-level staff were primarily women from a diverse range of backgrounds, leadership is all men. They’ve said to all staff on multiple occasions that they “do not care about office diversity” and “just hire the right people for the job” (direct quotes), which usually means hiring upper-level staff directly from their own network without the position ever being posted to the public. Any organization-wide issues concerning race, gender, or sexual assault (and there are many) can be expected to be dismissed as "toxic gossip", or at the very least not understood, by them. 

The CEO/founder rules out of fear with an iron fist, and he quickly snuffs out any whispers of dissent or organization by staff, using threats - ironically like the dictators that the organization prides itself on fighting against. He values perceived loyalty to him and the organization over actual work ethic or work produced, and prefers employees who stay quiet about highly inappropriate leadership and partner behavior. 

The CEO/founder issued a major layoff in 2019, which has been followed by the hemorrhaging of many other core staff members as they quit before things have the chance to become even worse. It's a shame, considering some of the amazing activists whose work HRF could have supported if not for atrociously poor and inappropriate leadership. I would never, under any circumstances, recommend that anyone look into working for, interning for, contracting with, or partnering with HRF. Speak to any former employee first.

review_title: Upper level management never held accountable
job_title: Associate in New York, NY
pros: There was incredible talent at the associate level. I learned from so many of my peers.
cons:
After being hired, a non-existent onboarding process should have been my first red flag about this organization. I was told HRF functioned like a startup, but this place has been around since the early 2000’s so you can imagine my confusion with this statement. There is no HR department who could answer specific questions about my role and job duties. There was no structure or reasoning behind anything that happened my first week. I learned one aspect of my role, and then I was alone without anyone delegating tasks or telling me what my daily responsibilities would be, or to notify me about any deadlines coming up. As an associate, I essentially ran my entire department by myself, doing the work of a manager or director, on an entry-level salary.

Morale was so low in the office. Associates were killing themselves to meet deadlines assigned to them by C-Suite execs, yet the executives would miss their own deadlines by weeks with no consequences, leading to more burdens on low level staff and accruing late fees for outsourcing materials and expedited shipping for events - the blame for which, of course, fell on the associates. Upper level staff were not held accountable to anything. The pay gap from Directors/C-Suite to Associates was astronomical, to the point where the workplace became a joke. 

There was no sense of boundaries between work-life balance, or appropriate workplace conduct. I was spoken to by C-Suite executives multiple times inappropriately. These interactions ranged from publicly shouting at me in front of colleagues and potential partners, to disclosing information about employee personal situations and reasons for termination.

The expectation was to make this job your entire life, while shouldering all the responsibility that upper level management can’t handle or refuses to be held accountable for.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The intelligence and vision of staff members, from interns to policy officers, is consistently impressive and inspiring. The mission attracts a compelling variety of talent and almost everyone within the organization is fully committed to doing everything they can to support HRF’s activist network.
cons:
Ultimately, this organization is disastrously managed and lacks the internal structures and stability needed to progress as a formidable voice on human rights issues. The organization’s finances have been in dire straits for more than five years and senior leadership often admits to “borrowing from Peter to pay Paul” - seeking more funding to pay for large debts incurred on previous events or programs that generate little support. Staff were often forced to put business expenses on their personal credit cards because the sole HRF credit card was repeatedly cut off or overdrawn. Some staff members aggregated debts of more than $20k with reimbursement slow to come. Donor support is highly skewed toward a few individuals, and many of the requirements for HRF’s most significant grants are not diligently followed. 

The treatment of women in the workplace has been discussed extensively in competing reviews on Glassdoor and I encourage those who read these reviews to appreciate that many of these employees with negative experiences worked directly with activists within the HRF network and voiced their concerns in addition to their own. Non-staff associated with the organization are still affected by its reputation and decisions to stand by offenders, and I personally know a number of individuals who feel uncomfortable with HRF’s politics but feel that they cannot speak out against the organization because they rely on it for funding and support and fear retaliation.

It is also critical to recognize that HRF’s holistic work environment encourages burnout and exhaustion, with threats often made to those who say they are struggling to maintain their workloads. Paranoia is endemic throughout the organization, much of this stemming from the CEO and senior leaders he has mentored, and an assumption that criticisms and questions about the organization and its structure are acts of sabotage or treason. For a considerable period of time, most employees at HRF were drawn from a pool of former interns or international consultants, with few coming to the organization with experience in other nonprofits or business organizations. This led to a culture of complacency within management and a disregard for new ideas. 

I was consistently threatened during my time at HRF for respectfully speaking up during meetings about decisions I felt would bankrupt the organization and personally watched countless employees break down on the job. Drug use, alcohol, and depression were rampant throughout the organization. Rather than demonize those who asked for help, HRF should strive to understand why its employees feel the need to self-medicate, particularly during stretches of time when staff are only sleeping 2-3 hours a night, rarely taking a weekend off, and often encouraged to work while on PTO. 

There are countless stories to share that can demonstrate how HRF has manipulated its employees and created untenable work environments. However, HRF has a way of always skirting over its flaws and pretending that those who speak out and are removed for it are rare dissenters or employees with a grudge — which has happened every few years as if on a timed cycle. I would recommend for anyone considering working for HRF to reach out to some of those who no longer work at HRF and find out more about their experiences. It takes a long time to recover from the abuse and reputation of HRF, and I would hate for more individuals to go through the difficult process of realizing that an organization promising good work does not deliver on those promises, for either its community or staff.

review_title: Do you care about human rights?  Don't work here!
job_title: Programs
pros:
I had the pleasure of meeting the most incredible and inspiring group of activists that continue their work and advocacy despite constant threats from their oppressive governments. The Oslo Freedom Forum is truly a one of a kind conference.

The vast majority of the coworkers I had were 100% dedicated to making the world a better place. Despite everything HRF subjected them to, they worked tirelessly to advance the values of human decency, universal liberty, democracy, and freedom for every individual languishing under the yoke of dictatorship.
cons:
Don’t believe the fawning, sycophantic reviews that have magically populated in past couple of months - despite the good work that the organization manages to do (in spite of its own best efforts), working at HRF was a constant struggle and drained the mind, body, and soul.

The organization is poorly managed, and absolutely has “founder syndrome.” The CEO reigns as a king and his word is final. On the more “benign" end, these decisions forced employees to scramble and change projects and programs at the very last minute with little notice - on the more sinister end, employees who had dedicated years of their lives to the organization were let go for no reason, or humiliatingly demoted to the point where they quit. 

HRF treated its female employees, to put it lightly, terribly (I too encourage others to read reviews from early 2020 and 2019 to hear more stories). Despite consistently making up over 80% of its workforce, women were not represented in C-Level positions until just recently. Women were denigrated and ridiculed in meetings for their ideas, only to see male employees take said ideas and receive acclaim for proposing them. Women who protested this hostile environment were belittled and gaslighted. 

Employees regularly worked 60+ hours a week without additional compensation, and working on the weekends, while not a requirement, was an absolute necessity if you wished to retain your job. 

A work-life balance was non-existent. Do not expect to be able to enjoy living in New York on a meager salary with the amount of work you will be expected to complete.
